ca.mcgill.ecse211.project

Class Odometer

  • java.lang.Object
    • ca.mcgill.ecse211.project.Odometer
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.lang.Runnable

    public class Odometer
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.lang.Runnable
    The odometer class keeps track of the robot's (x, y, theta) position.
    Author:
    Rodrigo Silva, Dirk Dubois, Derek Yu, Karim El-Baba, Michael Smith, Younes Boubekeur, Dimitrios Sinodinos, Jacob St-Laurent

      Overwrites y.

    • Method Detail

      • getOdometer

        public static Odometer getOdometer()
        Returns the Odometer Object. Use this method to obtain an instance of Odometer.
        Returns:
        the Odometer Object

      • getXyt

        public double[] getXyt()
        Returns the Odometer data.

        Writes the current position and orientation of the robot onto the odoData array. odoData[0] = x, odoData[1] = y; odoData[2] = theta;

        Returns:
        the odometer data.

      • run

        public void run()
        This method is where the logic for the odometer will run.
        Specified by:
        run in interface java.lang.Runnable

      • setTheta

        public void setTheta(double theta)
        Overwrites theta. Use for odometry correction.
        Parameters:
        theta - the value of theta

      • setX

        public void setX(double x)
        Overwrites x. Use for odometry correction.
        Parameters:
        x - the value of x

      • setXyt

        public void setXyt(double x,
          double y,
          double theta)
        Overrides the values of x, y and theta. Use for odometry correction.
        Parameters:
        x - the value of x
        y - the value of y
        theta - the value of theta in degrees

      • setY

        public void setY(double y)
        Overwrites y. Use for odometry correction.
        Parameters:
        y - the value of y

      • update

        public void update(double dx,
          double dy,
          double dtheta)
        Adds dx, dy and dtheta to the current values of x, y and theta, respectively. Useful for odometry.
        Parameters:
        dx - the change in x
        dy - the change in y
        dtheta - the change in theta
